comment: General note regarding alignment (a and s). Hahn lists a single column for 'nominative' which is presumably both A and S, and forms have been entered on the basis of this assumption

There is clearly an inclusive distinction, though in parts of his exposition Hahn treats this as a 'second form of the second person' rather than of the first person, and his translation of the inclusive duals is slightly odd 'I and you two' despite being in the dual column. However it seems likely that the 'two' has semantic scope over the whole group, not just the 'you', and the data has been coded on that assumption
Layout in source is a bit ambiguous, ('alaŋā or rā, reṇī' but consideration of other cells suggests that the scope of the part after 'or' gives disjunct suffixes, not whole words)
Hahn, Ferdinand. 1900. A Primer of the Asur Dukmā, a dialect of the Kolarian language. Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal. 69. 149-172.

There is no set specialised for 3rd person pronouns as distinct from demonstratives. The forms given here can function as e.g. 'tbis (on), he, she, it. The hi- forms are proximate and the hu- forms are remote

word: hiniā, hinirā, hinirenī, huniā, hunirā, hunirenī
hiniā, hinirā, hinirenī, huniā, hunirā, hunirenī
hikiŋā, hikiŋrā, hikiŋrenī , hukiŋā, hukiŋrā, hukiŋrenī
